Immature Mosquitoes - L

A Basic Aquatic Ecology Model

L.Rmd

For purposes of integrating the effects of movement and aquatic ecology, we assume each female lays oo eggs, so the total number of eggs laid each day in each site is:

ηt=oψqQt\begin{equation} \eta_t = o \psi_q Q_t \label{eq_nut} \end{equation}

We assume the number of immature mosquitoes in aquatic habitats, denoted LtL_t, is subject to density dependence, which could delay maturation or increase mortality. The maturating fraction is, θe−ξLt\theta e^{-\xi L_t} where ξ>0\xi>0, and surviving fraction is pLe−ζLtp_L e^{-\zeta L_t} where ζ>0\zeta>0. The parameters are site-specific, so that some habitats can vary in quality. The dynamics are:

Lt+1=ηt+pLe−ζLt(1−θe−ξLt)Lt.\begin{equation} L_{t+1} = \eta_t + p_L e^{-\zeta L_t} (1-\theta e^{-\xi L_t}) L_t. \label{eq_Lt} \end{equation}

The number of adult females emerging each day is half the mosquitoes who both survived and matured:

Λt+1=pLθe−(ξ+ζ)Lt2Lt\begin{equation} \Lambda_{t+1} = \frac{p_L \theta e^{-(\xi +\zeta) L_t} }{2} L_t \label{eq_Lambdat} \end{equation}

While this model is adequate for the needs of this study, the model may not robustly capture some relevant features of mosquito ecology or larval source management, such as when larval population structure and delays are important.
